page.name: EDITARBIOPRO
page.Resource: {div style="padding-left:10px;font-size:0.92em;"}{p style="margin-left:-10px;"}Tell your professional activity in a short paragraph explaining your professional achievements and interests. Look at these examples:{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}Lawyer specialised in intellectual property on the Internet. I participate in the defense of the rights of cultural industry, primarily in movie and music worlds. I am interested in management, development and dissemination of Creative Commons licenses.{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}Enologist at a winery whose wines are recognized with Guarantee of Origin. I work the full cycle of processing of the grapes and crianza. I combine my work in the laboratory with the role of public relations for the winery in media, marketing and events.{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}Telecommunications Engineer with experience in international accounts and, especially, development and management of civil projects in the Middle East. I work as a freelance and my goal is to facilitate business and professional relations between the Arab and Western cultures.{/p}{/div}

{div style="padding-left:10px;font-size:0.92em;"}{p style="margin-left:-10px;"}Describe in detail the responsibilities and objectives of your current job and previous work experience. We give you these examples:{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}I review, correct and supervise the arrival of original documents to the editorial. I prepare reports about the commercial viability of the proposals received.{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}Control of employee access to the building and identification of external visits. In turn, I manage the distribution of correspondence to all companies in our office building.{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}I run the business strategy of the company in the North: I attract clients and develop personalized proposals. In turn, I am advisor to presidency in Corporate Social Responsibility. I inform and advise them personally{/p}{/div}

{div style="padding-left:10px;font-size:0.92em;"}{p style="margin-left:-10px;"}Describe your degrees and the content of your training in masters, seminars, workshops or courses. Examples:{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}I did the Master 'Online communication' at the Autonomous University of La Rioja to strengthen my knowledge in Web 2.0 and its practical application in traditional media.{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}In the Summer 2011 I did a postgraduate degree in International Relations at the London Foreign Affairs School. The course included a four-week practice in the British Embassy in Lagos (Nigeria).{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}I hold the certificate of 'Hairdresser for institutional acts and protocol events', at Academy Nexus. The skills acquired in this course have been implemented in four stays in companies of this sector.{/p}{/div}

{div style="padding-left:10px;font-size:0.92em;"}{p style="margin-left:-10px;"}Describe your academic achievements:{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}I was awarded 'Extraordinary Prize' for best student at the University of Madrid when I finished my studies in Agronomy.{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}My project 'Conservation of wetlands' received Prost Foundation award for the best proposal for 2009.{/p}{p}{img src="@1@/img/dotListadoGris.gif" style="margin-right: 3px; margin-left: -10px; "}During my college years I was co-founder of the organization 'ProVegaEspaña'.{/p}{/div}

The weaknesses refer to all those elements, resources, skills and attitudes that the actor under analysis already has and that constitute barriers to its good working.({a href="http://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/An%C3%A1lisis_DAFO#Debilidades"}Definition obtained from Wikipedia{/a}).

Threats are negative situations outside the program or project that might be a menace to it. So eventually, an appropriate strategy to overcome them may be necessary ({a href="http://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/An%C3%A1lisis_DAFO#Amenazas"}Definition obtained from Wikipedia{/a}).

Strengths are those internal and positive elements that make the program, actor or project different from other ones of a similar class ({a href="http://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/An%C3%A1lisis_DAFO#Fortalezas"}Definición obtenida de Wikipedia{/a}).

Opportunities are those external positive situations which are generated in the environment and once identified you can take advantage of them ({a href="http://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/An%C3%A1lisis_DAFO#Oportunidades"}Definition obtained from Wikipedia{/a}).

The resources of a public community can be shared by its members in the different communities in which they participate, as long as they have permission to do so. This availability depends on the type of resource and the role of each member.
Types of resources available for each user

The roles of the members of the community, by levels of permissions in the same ordered from highest to lowest, can be: administrator, supervisor and user. Each role incorporates the privileges of the immediately lower. So, a resource available for a supervisor will also be for an administrator, but not for a user.

Application settings for integration with Share Point
This page serves to configure integration with Share Point on the platform. This integration allows when creating a link type resource that aims at a Share Point file can be:
Download the attached file (the Share Point file)
Check if the file of the latest version of the resource and the file in Share Point are aligned. If they are not having to create a new version

To obtain the client data ID, Tenate and Secret Directory of the client, it is necessary to register an application in Azure Active Directory. At the end of the form there is a link to the manual that explains step by step the instructions to be followed to register and configure said application.
These URLs are necessary for the Azure AD application to function properly and obtain the data from the fields above. Follow the manual to know where you have to configure them.
Before saving you must follow the manual steps and register an Azure Active Directory application if you are not already registered
Creation and application configuration manual in Azure AD to integrate Share Point
We are going to https://portal.azure.com. You will ask us to log in to our Office account if we do not have the session.
Once logged in, we open the lateral menu and select ‘Azure Active Directory’.
Now we have to go to 'Application Registry'. Once here we must give 'new record' to add a new application.
In the next step we simply give the application a name, and the rest of the fields leave them as they come by default.
Once registered, we will see the application information. For them we are going to 'general information'. Here we have two of the data we need to configure Share Point on the platform:
We copy those values ​​and put them in the corresponding field of the SharePoint configuration form (go to the form)

The next field we have to fill is the client secret (Client Secret). This data must be generated in the 'certificates and secrets' section. Here we give 'new customer secret' and give it a name and an expiration. This secret has a maximum duration of 24 months, so if it expires it would have generated that a new one.
Once created, we must copy the code generated in 'value'.

Next, we head to ‘authentication’. In this step we have to add the Redirection URLs that our application will have. In principle it is only necessary to configure three, which will point to the login service, but they could be configured more in case it was necessary. To do this we give ‘add a platform’

We will get several options to choose and select Web. Then we will write one of the URLs that are given in the form, the rest we add them in the next step since at this time it only allows you to add one.
We add the other two URLs. In the end we must have three.
The URLs that we have to add are those that appear in the Share Point configuration form
It is mandatory that all redirection urls have HTTPS, otherwise it will not allow redirections
The next step is to add the application permits. To configure them we must go to 'API permits', and once there we give 'add a permit'
We will have to play with the Microsoft Graph and Share Point permits
When adding a permit we must choose whether it will be a delegated or application permit. Final permits must be similar to the following:
At this point, the application will already be configured to integrate Share Point, the only step that is that an administrator grants the necessary permits so that we can use it.

To grant these permits we have to go to the form and click on the link or give the save button, either of the two is worth. We will be asked for the credentials of an administrator user to accept the permits.
Be careful before saving or giving the link, we first have to have this application configured.

Public communities are governed by the following standards:
Any user can make a member and contribute to the community (vote, comment, upload resources, etc.).
Non-member users of the community and unregistered internet users will be able to browse the community and consult any of its contents.
Public communities are visible in the Board of Communities and their contents in Internet search engines.
Any Gnoss user can make a member and contribute to the community (vote, comment, upload resources, etc.).
GNOSS non -members of the community and Internet users not registered in GNOSS will be able to navigate the community and consult any of its contents.
Public communities are visible in the GNOSS communities directory and their contents in Internet search engines.
Private communities are governed by the following standards:
Only users who receive an invitation to participate in it can be members of a private community.
GNOSS users who are not members cannot access these private communities.
Private communities are not visible in the GNOSS Communities Board of Directors, and their contents are not visible from Internet search engines.
Restricted communities are governed by the following standards:
Any user can request access to be a member of the community and contribute to the community (vote, comment, upload resources, etc.).
Non -members of the community and unregistered Internet users will be able to navigate the community and consult any of its contents.
Public Communities of Restricted Access are visible in the Board of Communities of GNOSS and their contents in Internet search engines.

page.Resource: We use own and third party cookies to improve your browsing experience. More information in {a href="@1@"}Cookies policy{/a}.

The cookies used on this website are categorised, and you can read about each category below to enable or block some or all of the respective cookies. When you disable categories that were previously enabled, all cookies assigned to that category will be deleted from your web browser. In addition, you can see a list of cookies assigned to each category, and detailed information about them, in the cookie statement.

These are cookies that allow the party responsible for them to monitor and analyse the behaviour of users of the websites to which they are linked, including the quantification of the impact of advertisements. The information collected through this type of cookies is used to measure the activity of the websites, application or platform, in order to introduce improvements based on the analysis of the usage data of the users of the service.
